data.text: Bike Touring in the Rain without a Raincoat

Newbie question... What do folks actually do about rain? So far I've focused on keeping my stuff dry so I can sleep dry. But I don't wear a raincoat under the assumption that I'm so wet with sweat already, some actual water won't make a difference. Is this normal? What do others do? For context, it's summer in south-eastern Canada so temperatures range from 22-32. I started out as a road cyclist so I'm wearing bibs and a jersey (it's what I'm comfortable in).
At 32 enjoy the rain. I have a poncho when it is colder. Nice breezes from below so I don't get wet from sweat, I also have fenders. The aerodynamics are horrible.

data.author: Jason Roussel

data.text: To me, 22 C is where the rain will start feeling cold. Below that I'll put on my raingear but - and this is crucially important - you can't just pull on Gore-Tex on bare skin; you need some intermediate layer. Yes, some rain garments do have a mesh inner lining that's supposed to deal with that but, no, in my experience they don't work. The key to understanding permeable clothing is that the sweat from your skin has to actually evaporate into steam BEFORE it reaches the outer layer. Merino wool or silk work orders of magnitude better than the synthetic linings of most rainwear. It may seem strange and counter-intuitive to wear a long-sleeved wool shirt in summer, but once you've tried it I promise you'll become a convert. It will take heat from your skin to evaporate the sweat so it can escape through the pores of the garment - and it will cool you down at the same time. Win-win!
data.author: Torsten Lif

data.text: Breathable waterproof with large pit-zips. Ventilation is more important than fabric breathability for cycling as no expensive fabric can output the moisture at the rate you generate active cycling. Even a windproof works ok. You will get wet eventually. It's more about stopping the wind-chill causing evaporative cooling. I carry waterproof overtrousers, but don't use them unless really cold and stormy. In normal rain, just let legs get wet...your skin is waterproof and soon dries!
data.author: Steve Holland

data.text: wet legs mean wet feet, and that's no fun.
data.author: Hugh Warrington

data.text: in showery weather, not a problem. In cold wet weather, only real way of keeping feet totally dry is overtrousers over gaiter style waterproof overshoes and waterproof socks. Overkill for most situations, but a method that works. Water will always run down legs into shoes/socks unless there is a double overlap. Sealkin socks on their own are a good comprise, as as they get wet, they act like a wetsuit, keeping warm layer of water next to skin. As a UK cyclist, I've developed this strategy over the years, and it's the one that works for me. Dress to expect to get wet eventually and your prepared. Dress expecting to keep totally dry and your in for trouble!üòâ

data.text: yep, the water eventually runs down skin into sock. Also not the most robust, but once they fail, they are still useful as a windproof/warm wet style sock! I also use them for stand up Paddle-boarding with a diving boot on top. A good bit of kit.
data.author: Steve Holland

data.text: Number 1, stay warm, if it is hot I don't bother with waterproofs, I also wear quick drying clothes (it prevents chaffing). Everything is double bagged, once by the pannier, then again with bin bags, but remember to replace the bin bags regularly as friction will make holes in them. Money and docs go in a ziploc bag, again, replace when needed. Remember, nothing is 100% reliable.
data.author: Steven Hawkswell

data.text: Wicking fabrics, wool or synthetic. jacket and pants are wind barrier only, 'cause you're going to be wet no matter what. Wicking and windstoppers control evaporation to keep you from getting too hot or too cold. keep a spare dry set if stopped for a long time in cold weather if you don't wear wool.
data.author: Larye Parkins

data.text: When it is really hot, and there are downpours during rainy season, I use a rain cape. It is fairly heavy but 100% waterproof, and lots of air gets underneath and around my body to keep me cool. It is also bright yellow, so that I cannot be easily missed, even by vehicles with poor windscreen wipers. If it is moderately warm, a waterproof jacket with pit zips, and shorts. Underneath I wear wicking layers. Usually a merino base layer. If I know I will be in the rain all day, waterproof socks. Yes I will get moist from sweat, but the wicking keeps the skin relatively dry, and merino wool is warm, even when moist. f it is cold I will also wear waterproof rain pants, mostly to avoid wind chill on my legs. And a waterproof thermal skull cap under my helmet.

data.text: On one of my tours of the PNW, I rode with a lot of rain. I remember stopping at a Mom & Pop shop and I seen a newspaper on the counter and I asked what the forecast was. The lady told me, Honey, this is the PNW we don't care what the forecast is, we are going to do whatever we were going to do anyways regardless of what happens with the weather. I appreciated the logic in that. I decided to ride in the rain and keep my clothing in my panniers dry. It worked great until I ran out of clothes, then I rented a room and washed and dried all my gear and started again in the morning. It took a while but I got used to it and the only other problem was the saddle sores from riding in the wet clothes. I really got to get back out there and do some more touring.
